Yep, one `appsettings.{environment}.json` for each environment is one approach. The SaaS hosting correctly sets the `ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT` when the application starts up which is why [the environment specific extension methods work](https://docs.kentico.com/developers-and-admins/configuration/saas-configuration#environment-identification-extension-methods).
Many teams already populate a configuration file in a CD pipeline using something like [variables and variables groups in Azure DevOps](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/library/variable-groups?view=azure-devops\&tabs=azure-pipelines-ui%2Cyaml#create-a-variable-group).
You can also store variables in Xperience with [a custom settings module](https://docs.kentico.com/x/create_basic_module_guides). You will likely want to exclude this settings object type in the `repository.config` to prevent overwriting environment data with local data. This approach can be convenient but requires you to secure configuration with [role management](https://docs.kentico.com/x/7IVwCg).
Once we have Azure Key Vault support for SaaS you'll have an additional option.
